title: The Forbidden Fruit - Temptation and Dilemma For Traditional Asset Managers to Invest in Crypto
body:
*I have been trying to develop my framework as a traditional investors to get exposure of crypto assets over past \~12 months. After the recent shocking events, I finally have a chance to look back and summarize my chain of thinking here* 

**The Temptation** 

I explained in details the struggle China-focused US dollar private funds currently facing in my previous article “Paradigm Shift of Private Investment in China”. In summary, the global theme has shifted and will be “competition and confrontation” for the near-to-mid term. As a result, although many reluctant to admit, golden times has ended for US dollars investors who enjoyed the glory days backing up hyped growth in the consumer internet companies, which inevitably turns into “disorderly expansion of capital“ - much as I dislike Jim Chanos' disturbing pride and prejudice towards China, I am paraphrasing his quote - “new economy companies” in China like a pig on LSD, you never know which way it’s going to run. Sadly enough, the crazy days are behind us. 

With the backdrop of decoupling of globalization, resources and capital are guided towards national interests, where “renewable energy" stays at the very core of investment for the next decade. Faced with new reality, US dollar investors have to adapt their strategy to spend more time on once they regarded less glamorous. However, the adaptation is never easy. Faced with down-to-earth founders often without fancy resume, crowed investors sitting on the ground sitting on supply chains, and the fact most profitable companies don’t desire to raise money, white-collar golden child soon find himself in a very different and high competitive environment. 

Despaired and anxious about deployment and future fundraising as these investors are, here comes crypto which might provide a possible solution.

The narrative and charm of crypto is naturally the oasis in the desert for US dollar investors in China. First of all, the 2020/2021 bull cycle hyped unprecedented FOMO among global asset allocators. The narrative of long-term mega trend once again posed the image of a hype-growing industry with enormous TAM, which is a dazzling fundraising theme at least most of LPs won’t mind talking about. And the same time, entrepreneurs are mostly young and share similar language with those investors rather than the embarrassment talking with manufacturing veterans. Last not but not the least, given the outright ban of majority of crypto-related activities in China, regulatory risk from the Chinese regulators are less of a concern, as most of the companies will not contact business in China by default.  

In short, crypto provides China-focused US dollar investor a comfortable playfield to maximized their competitive advantage of “combine the best of west and east” instead of head-to-head street fight with their domestic peers in more traditional sectors. 

Despite the recent fallout of crypto assets and negative headlines, with quality of talented joined and amount of capital raised in this cycle, my long term believe in crypto as a technology and asset class remains strong. I very much agree with what Matt Huang put out in the latest LP letter “The tourist investor class has thankfully decamped. We believe the next 12-24 months will be an exceptionally fruitful time for building and investing in crypto.”

To put a tag on my conviction level, I am cleaning up my ADR positions and rolling into BTC. 

**The Dilemma** 

However, traditional private funds are not crypto native, hence hands are tied at the starting line. Premium and expenses have to be paid as your experience is never full until you are rugged. 

I started seriously diving into the rabbit hole of crypto in early 2021, after missing at least two bull cycles. The first is when I was in college, where my classmate was buying BTC at \~$1,000 on some platforms that may not exist today. That was the time I heard the term Bitcoin and that’s it. Fast-forward to late 2017 when I was an investment banking analyst, crypto-assets were talked about few times during lunch break with some of my colleagues, I gave some the “told-you-so” look after the ICO collapse. Slap on my face, some of friends stayed on and made it. 

So this time, I am serious. I took the entire MIT Gensler crypto course online and did some in depth research and reference chat. I quickly built my conviction not only based on the recognition of the  cryptographic technology but more on how the narrative of crypto fit into the current state of world. The idea of decentralization, which might not be entirely good, seems inevitable looking at series of social unrests and hyperinflation happening around the world. And at the point when US congress started to debating the regulation of crypto, I am no longer worried about the existence of crypto as they always settle. 

So next question is how to get exposure to crypto as a traditional asset manager. I quickly to the conclusion that it is unrealistic for us to catch alpha opportunities. Obvious fund admin reasons: a) as a US dollar fund we don’t have the infrastructure to do token investment yet; b) pure crypto native deals are mostly club deals with tickets which is not meaningful to us; c) we don’t have the expertise to manage token positions even if a) and b) are resolved; and d) most deals are VC in nature, level of risks may beyond our mandate. However, I think the key concern that holding me back is I think crypto investment requires a higher bar than traditional tech investment as a) much more sub-sectors; and b) each of the sectors are exploding fast, as such the investment is also PoW unless we are 7\*24 dedicated to this sector, I am not even convinced myself that I can catch the alpha. 

I think same applies to most of the crypto-wannabe TriFi funds.  

 
 **A Possible Solution** 

So here is what I thought would make sense to solve the dilemma. It’s hard for us to catch the real alpha without bearing with bottomless downside, but at least I think we could enjoy smart beta. First and foremost, as even 3AC labeled at their website, crypto is a highly speculative asset class, it is important to draw down the  firebreak, i.e. set a up-limit percentage of overall crypto allocation. Say 10% of the total fund, then extreme case scenario if all wiped out, is 10% and that is what we are comfortable with. 

Then we construct our portfolio with two main strategies, i.e. FoF investment and direct investment. By investing in crypto-native funds, we are putting our capital in the specialized hands who are better dedicated and equipped with the knowledge and network to catch alpha from a closer seat to the market. At the same time, these funds could help us get crypto exposure without converting fiat into crypto despite still a paying a premium partly in the form of carry (god, some of the funds charges really high carry). Also by engaging with GP of the fund, we could learn and better blende in with crypto people and potential lead to deal sourcing.

For FoF portfolio, we are focused to diversify a) positioning / strategy of the fund; and 2) vintage of the fund, of which the latter might be more decisive as at the end of the day it is a high beta industry. Follow this strategy, we have invested two of the established crypto-native funds. To be honest, their return might not be skyrocketing compared with smaller first time fund, given their total size and vintage, but as a start, track record and industry endorsement matters more to us.

Then the other arm is direct investment. For this piece, the strategy is to investment top companies in top sub-sectors. As these companies a) are of the size that we could deploy meaningful capital; b) are often highly profitable with strong balance (supposedly) to navigate circles; c) have the possibility of listing on traditional stock market; and d) are endorsed by renowned crypto native investors. Although valuation of these companies are often at premium, 3x returns can be justified in most cases. 

So with this criteria, it is not hard to reach the conclusions that exchanges, centralized platforms and infrastructure providers are the areas we need to spend more time on. It also crosschecked from the deal access prospective. Unlike web2, where China has its own market due to GFW, crypto is a global industry and to be honest most of the high quality projects are born in the West, where we have limited access. China background team is the angle we can play, but I come to the realization that Chinese teams are normally more capable of operation and product, but hard to standout in terms of creativity. 

At last, we are still humble, to minimize the risk, we adopts a basket approach by reducing ticket size to the extent make sense so that we could invest more companies. 

Follow this logic, we invested in an exchange and a regional asset manager. 

**How I get REKT and Lessons Learned** 

Shipped has sailed and cruising steadily until the UST-3AC storm hit. Sadly, one of the investment went south. Even I am prepared for this kind of event, but the speed of the downfall kept me deeply in shock. Matt has a detailed but precious description of what happened in his LP letter.

My lessons specific to this event is a) underestimated the leverage in the system and cushion required to define safe; b) underestimated the systematic risks of lacking of industry wide risk control standard like Basel III; at the end of the day, it is a financial system. I was naive to be convinced the risk system is robust by giving the answer that we survived March 12 crush what worse can happen; c) overestimated the stability a bank like system can be without backstop institutions like Fed and FDIC. 

The downfall of the CeFi platform resulted from lack of transparency in disclosure and risk management will put a serious blow to the CeFi model as a whole at least for the near term especially for yield-marketing platforms, given a) crypto yield inevitably diminishing given more capital arbitraging in a deleveraging market; b) yield become less attractive in the US dollar interest raising cycle; and c) trust amongst retail investors are deeply hurt.

However, if it only because of the reasons below, I will feel better, as it is more of a mis-judgement on business model. The thing that REKT me most is the direct reason led to the downfall of the company is the mismanagement. I will skip details here given sensitivity. It really taught me a lesson about moral hazard and the dark side of this industry. I was of the view that this is a decentralized industry that everyone can be hero regardless of the past, but now I am leaning towards the elite theory. Also I will require full-set individual background for each of the investment.

After all these, I am still optimistic as most of the Builders that crypto ecosystem will emerge smarter and more resilient. However, the pressure is real. I think the majority of the strategy still intact, but some adjustments are needed, which I am working hard on.

*(I will discuss my thinking on my thinking on areas to focus looking ahead in another article)*
yuyv

title: RIP traditional audits. Code4rena broke smart contract security—for good
body:
[Code4rena’s](https://code4rena.com) audit contest model represents a clean break from the traditional audit model that’s been imported from the web2 world.

The intense rigor of a C4 audit contest finds more bugs faster than a traditional audit at a better value:

* **Rigor.** It is impossible for any audit firm to match the volume of expertise and intensity of competition a one-week Code4rena contest can bring together on a codebase.
* **Speed.** You can start a new audit contest with C4 in 48 hours. If you want to book a top traditional audit firm, get ready to wait.
* **Value.** Compare 1-6 engineer weeks for trad audits vs 20+ engineer weeks for a one-week C4 audit contest—and C4 will have your bugs reported to you at the end of the week.

At this point in its evolution, evidence from numerous contests indicates that a C4 audit contest unequivocally offers a higher level of security coverage than a traditional audit.

## It’s all about that risk

In web2, the max risk in a typical app is that user credit cards, emails, passwords get exposed (again).

The max risk for web3 is dramatically greater—*poof goes my net worth!*—but the way most audit offerings are set up, you might think we’re dealing with the same risk level.

The most common approach for both web2 and web3 security is to hire a traditional audit firm to review the project and staff the audit with 1-2 auditors for 1-3 weeks—sometimes more time for good measure.

But one of these things is not like the other.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/A4SjOWSKAm26KTBsoYM4c.png?height=1092&width=978)

Let’s talk about how these are different.

Contemporary security processes and infrastructure mitigates 99.9% of the risk in web2 for most users:

* two-factor auth
* spam filters
* fraud detection
* reversible transactions
* robust legal frameworks
* educated law enforcement

With this backstop in place, traditional security audits in web2 are not about preventing all hacks. They're about ensuring trust, reducing liability and cost, and preventing embarrassment.

The infrastructure and process in place form a safety net that reduces the max risk for even the most poorly secured web2 apps.

## web3: There is no net

The web2 safety nets just don't apply in the smart contract world.

Once code is in production, the only backstop is sufficiently large white hat bounties to encourage responsible disclosure.

But **bug bounties are about post-production risk management**. And with the kind of risk level that exists for smart contracts, every project should be working to reduce as many bugs as possible from making it to production.

The stakes are too high to just take the casual web2 approach and say:

`git commit -m ‘lgtm, we've got bounties anyway yolo :shipit:’`

The high level of risk is already reflected in the market-driven pricing of traditional smart contract audits. Projects take security seriously and they do indeed spend for it.

## High stakes, high prices

**It's common for projects to spend $100,000 to $500,000 or more on an audit from a reputed firm.**

For this money, projects are often getting 1-6 engineer weeks of code review.

At the end of the day, money spent on audits is based primarily on the brand and reputation of the firm. The old "Nobody got fired for buying IBM" is now "Nobody got flamed for hiring \[premium audit brand\]."

But the question is: ***what are people getting for the money?***

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/aqiv-9YJUqnyPTq8-CU2Q.png?height=1338&width=1352)

**Code4rena’s unique model was designed by people who pay for audits *and* highly value security.** Mechanism designer [Scott Lewis](https://twitter.com/scott_lew_is) and fellow Code4rena DAO bootstrapper [Zak Cole](https://twitter.com/0xzak) built Code4rena first to meet the needs of their own projects:

* They wanted to pay for audits they knew would be top quality.
* They didn’t want to delay shipping to wait for top tier audit firms to become available.
* If they could ensure every dollar spent on security went as far as it could, even better.

Since the beginning, Code4rena has offered unmatched value when comparing engineer weeks of code review. And meanwhile, the quantity and quality of Code4rena’s competition has continued to increase.

Where a traditional audit might have 1-6 engineer weeks of code review, **a typical week-long C4 audit contest today involves 20 engineer weeks**, with many exceeding that number.

But even setting aside the value gap, **there are too many open questions for any one-entity traditional audit:**

* Are we getting the firm's best auditors?
* Are the subset of people working full-time as auditors the best in the industry?
* How do the auditors' skill levels and approach compare to what the contracts are going to see in the dark forest of grey hats and black hats?
* How do we know the auditors are operating at peak performance?
* How do we know the auditors with the best subject matter expertise on the uniqueness of our contracts are the ones doing the audits?

These questions are not a knock on traditional audit firms, but they indicate a fundamental mismatch given the high stakes of web3.

## Nontraditional risks require a nontraditional model

If a black hat has to only be right once while 1-2 traditional auditors have to only be wrong once, that's a pretty thin line of defense when the stakes are this high.

If 30 auditors have to be wrong, the odds are clearly improved in the favor of defense. And if those auditors are competing with each other to get paid based on what they find, all the better!

Competitive incentives ensure that the best and most valuable work gets rewarded the highest, rather than the best brand being rewarded for their investment and branding and their past reputation.

Because of the elegance of the mechanism, the largest payouts go to those who find the highest severity *and* hardest-to-find bugs.

Competition is how Code4rena works. And it's *why* Code4rena works.

## Consider the results

Thanks to information made public by Code4rena sponsors, we have some hard data to compare the results of traditional audits both before and after Code4rena audit contests.

### NFTX

NFTX ran two one-week Code4rena audit contests in 2021—one in [May](https://code4rena.com/contests/2021-05-nftx-contest) and one in [December](https://code4rena.com/contests/2021-12-nftx-contest) covering iterations made following the May contest. A traditional audit firm reviewed the same code following the second audit contest and identified one medium severity issue.

As NFTX’s audits took place in the first nine months of Code4rena’s growth, these contests “only” had 11 engineer weeks of code review, still dramatically surpassing the coverage of the traditional audit that followed.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/geo2Ocevpanr8Qd-V1Sau.png?height=569&width=1200)

### Aura Finance

The Aura Finance contest represents a look at how contest turnout has run in recent months.

This audit represented 65 engineering weeks and found 1 high and 22 medium severity issues, with a 6 engineer week audit scheduled *after* the Code4rena contest turning up no highs or mediums.

Note that because the latter audit was 6 engineer weeks performed by one auditor, C4’s two-week audit contest was complete in a third of the time despite having 10 times as much review.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/euJRrL3oF8MkK0KIicVP5.png?height=569&width=1200)

### OpenSea Seaport

The Seaport engineering team came to us with a challenge:

* they’d just finished an audit by a reputed firm which had turned up no high or medium findings
* the engineers were eager to see another set of eyes review their code
* they wanted to launch ASAP
* the codebase had a high level of complexity
* all auditors needed to be KYC’d based on legal constraints

In order to draw talented experts and even entire audit firms into urgently reviewing code, we collaborated with OpenSea to create a $1 million prize pool.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/aZdT-W830eCeKSZ5urefX.png?height=569&width=1200)

The result demonstrated a win for the flexibility afforded by Code4rena. Where we typically recommend a pool that we believe wardens will find fair in the context of other contests, projects that want to draw a greater number or more specialized set of eyes are able to add to the contest pool.

In this case, OpenSea’s large audit contest prize pool was able to draw in a number of brand new competitors who were able to contribute to securing Seaport, finding two high severity and two medium severity issues which had not been discovered.

The Code4rena community was still able to deliver 42 engineer weeks worth of code review even with the last-minute KYC constraint.

We were able to start their contest just a couple days after our first conversation and OpenSea was able to ship Seaport securely and on schedule.

## Efficient, effective, rigorous

As these examples illustrate, Code4rena is an efficient and effective model which delivers auditing rigor at scale and speed that simply cannot be matched by traditional audit firms.

C4 is the only approach I've seen in smart contract security that is natively designed from first principles in order to cost-efficiently solve the unique challenges of the space.

I can say this objectively; I didn't have anything to do with coming up with Code4rena as an idea. I just saw the concept on Twitter and was blown away by its potential and joined the discord, eager to help.

I'm still blown away every week by how innovative Code4rena’s model is. The word ‘disruptive’ is overused but it’s hard to find a term more apt.

“*Good, fast, cheap: pick two”* is the well-known trilemma.

With Code4rena’s security model, web3 projects can **pick all three.**

## Code4rena contests offer superior quality, speed, and value compared to traditional audit firms—and it's not even close.

**But you don’t have to take our word for it. Here’s what some Code4rena sponsors have said:**

“Code4rena’s open audits serve to ensure as many security experts have their eyes on our code as we can. With a significant reward pool, the open audit process has proven to be more cost effective and produce better results than most contracted auditing firms. Given the performance of the wardens in our most recent audit (in comparison to our previously contracted audits), we plan to have the Code4rena Wardens review any significant codebase changes going forward.” —[Swivel team](https://swivel.substack.com/p/code4rena-audit-competition-post)

*“Having experience with both, I definitely recommend that devs go with C4 for auditing instead of audit companies.”* —Alex Gausman, NFTX

\*“Code4rena should be a standard part of every protocol’s security practice/processes.” \*—[SpadaBoom](https://twitter.com/spadaboom1/status/1522192780709310464?s=21&t=JGG_bg75P4u2dWw78BGGew), Badger

## Cream of the crop, at your service

One of the challenges mentioned earlier with traditional audits is you have no real way to assess the capability of individual auditors.

In some cases—particularly during development or in review of minor changes—it can make sense to have a solo audit or a small 3-person audit, but the traditional model can leave you both waiting *and* guessing as to the quality you’ll get.

Top-tier Code4rena wardens have proven themselves in open competition against the best in the industry. For cases where you need a quick review of a small scope, we can match your project to a top-tier C4 warden with immediate availability who can deliver a personal solo audit of a small scope with a quick turnaround at an affordable rate.

## You can start an audit with Code4rena in 48 hours. Seriously.

Code4rena now offers:

* **Open audit contests**
* **Private audit contests** (under NDA, with KYC)
* **Solo audits by top wardens for small scopes** — available on 24 hour notice with 48 hour total turnaround from request
* **Three top-tier wardens in a small “versus” battle** (both public and private options available)
* **Presort service** — let us deduplicate wardens’ submitted findings for you

Just [reach out to Tre on Telegram](https://t.me/trebienxyz) or in the #i-want-c4-to-audit-our-code channel in the [C4 Discord](https://discord.gg/code4rena).


---

P.S. Our DAO (governed by the $ARENA token on Polygon) is constantly growing and we’d love to have you part of what we’re building. We have big plans for this year and lots of ways to get involved. Hop into [our Discord](https://discord.gg/code4rena) and get involved.

title: Suicide Letter
body:
The time has come to release the clutch. 

I have tried my best, for so long. At every fork and milestone, I did what I needed to do. What I was taught to do. What I was told to do. I’ve searched endlessly for creative inspiration; to try and find a version of my self who could contribute in a way that brings people smiles and joy and laughter and comfort and reflection. 

I have spent a lifetime being an ornament on other people’s trees and when the season ends and the tree is brought down, I am stored in a box until needed again.

The details of my particular situation are of no consequence. My story is not unique. I am one of many, in a similar boat, in a raging sea, pleading for calm while learning to surf the waves of exhaustion that perpetually roll over me.

I’m not convinced removing myself from this tormented Sea will have the intended effect. It seems there has always been a voice inside who knows, insists even, that death is not a solution when one takes ones own life. It merely repeats again from a different node in a different time. But if you must, then do so and rediscover the futility of the act. This knowing has been the only thing stopping me, the Fool inside is persuasive and afraid.

The Fool is also the one writing this letter, as another attempt to thwart me from my task.

Given the decades long history of this dance of friction between us, I always know who wins. It is never me. 

Until next time.

title: Music Label 3.0
body:
Phlote (pronounced "float") is a MUSIC CURATION PROTOCOL AND LABEL. We’ve built technology that allows us to scale our ability to identify, invest in, and amplify talented emerging artists alongside our network of independent labels, creator focused blockchain protocols, and early fans. 

Our process for finding music relies on a passionate community of music lovers who select which songs we release using a process that’s open and transparent. We offer artists a straightforward deal structure that’s available to any artist and bypasses the power dynamics, politics, and barriers of the traditional music industry. 

To unlock the power of the internet for artists, we’re formed to allow anyone with an internet connection and crypto wallet to help discover and invest in the next generation of stars. 

We love music and the artists who create it.  Our mission is to provide a path to creative freedom for artists by helping them maximize the visibility and value of their work.

The problem is, nearly all artists rely on streaming revenue as their primary means of income.  Without skills, resources, or means to tour or make high quality merch, most artists must make ends meet on $.0003 per stream, a challenge that’s nearly impossible to overcome. 

To put things into perspective, a recording artist must cut through Spotify’s 80,000 daily uploads and generate one million streams to earn enough money to pay one month’s rent. Artists must first gain visibility and then reach scale to have any chance to make a living as a musician.

This is a problem faced by millions of independent creators globally, regardless of their level of talent. 

Imagine if musicians were fairly compensated for the value they bring to billions of listeners? 

Fans are not immune. 

Early fans break artists across social media every day, but have no way to be compensated for the work they do. The most passionate fans helps elevate emerging artist out of obscurity and onto the radar of editorial outlets and eventually big labels. Think about the DJ, who spends much of her time finding obscure music to introduce to an audience, effectively helping to break new music. There’s tremendous value early tastemakers deliver to the music ecosystem, although there has been no way for them to capture it. Music labels are the only parties positioned to profit from discovery and rely on the signal generated by fans as their A&R function. 

Just like artists, fans are not getting paid for the value they create!

What if we built a system that allowed artists and fans to get compensated fairly?

All of this is possible with blockchain technology and non-fungible tokens (NFTs) - digital deeds that give any piece of digital content scarcity on the internet. The emergence of NFTs has created a global market for music that’s liquid, expanding, and favors up and coming artists. Now there’s a way to design skin-in-the-game incentives that allow artists to get paid a non-commoditized price for their work and for fans to profit from discovering new artists and helping them break.

In the old world, labels provided the capital and distribution.  Those resources can now be offered to artists, in part, by their super fans. Decentralized labels can enable this by using two components:

1. Decentralized Curation Protocol (voting)
2. Decentralized Marketplace (monetization)
3. Distribution (music sharing)

Decentralized Curation - At the foundation of Phlote is a curation protocol that rewards curators who are able to identify good music as voted on peer-to-peer. 

Our music curation process relies on a global community of music lovers who decide the music we sell as NFTs in exchange for a share of proceeds from NFT sales. The curation engine capitalizes on the public nature of blockchains to create a system that’s 100% transparent, permissionless and globally accessible to anyone with an internet connection and crypto wallet to participate in. 

Decentralized Marketplace - Breaking new artists now requires finding hundreds of fans versus millions and is likely to happen on marketplaces as much as it happens on streaming platforms. Number of transactions is the new follower count. 

For a decentralized label, the marketplace serves two functions. The marketplace is how the community monetizes it’s taste in music and enables artists to identify their core fans.  

By connecting our curation protocol to Zora’s decentralized marketplace protocol, we’ve created a pathway for any artist to mint music on the Ethereum blockchain without the restriction of gas fees. The bridge will allow for curation on [phlote.xyz](http://phlote.xyz/) to automatically launch NFT auctions on Zora, protocol-to-protocol. Phlote operates a custom contract that directs funds automatically to curators and artists. The DAO’s share of the sales proceeds is recirculated to the DAO treasury and used to fund fees for future artists.

Distribution (music sharing). Once an album is upvoted through the curation protocol, and sold on Zora, the next step is to amplify the artist and music. Today, the best interest of the artists and early supporters to look to traditional distribution platforms as the best place to reach a mass audience because that’s where they exist. YouTube and streaming platforms are utilized to serve as marketing for digital assets that exist on the blockchain. A wholly owned terrestrial radio station placed as distribution on top of a label would be powerful. Trad radio is a space that’s undervalued to new media/social media platforms, but for music continues to hold high value and cultural significance.  

Music social media is an interesting way to conceptualize what decentralized distribution could look like that takes advantage of music ownership as status, music collection as connective tissue, and the power of human recommendations over algorithms.  Imagine a social music network where each user’s profile is a playlist. 

We foresee a future where all next gen media networks are designed to be powered by the human recommendations of their community using the components discussed above. Using blockchain technology to combine community curation, ownership, distribution unlocks the global power of the internet for artists and enables a new class of participants to create, curate, and invest in media and IP for the first time ever.

title: Modular Application-Specific Blockchains
body:
The majority of Decentralized Applications available today are built with smart contracts deployed on top of existing blockchains (Ethereum, Avalanche, Solana, etc.). Smart contracts built on the same blockchains would then be part of a shared environment. In this article I want to touch up on why this can be better improved upon.

### Shortcomings

Building complex decentralized applications using smart contracts deployed on top of existing blockchains isn’t perfect, and could even be considered as sub-optimal. Here’s why:

* **Lack of Flexibility**

  dApps are often developed with a specific blockchain in mind, and thus a specific programming language and virtual machine. The dApp would then be limited to the capabilities of the underlying blockchain itself. For example, dApps built on the Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM) would inherit whatever limitations the EVM has.
* **Lack of Sovereignty**

  dApps that run on a shared environment face limited sovereignty. For example, if the devs or community wanted to do a fork or upgrade the smart contract, they would have to coordinate with and depend upon the underlying blockchain’s governance.
* **Sub-Optimal Performance**

  All dApps in the same blockchain are run by the same Virtual Machine. These smart contracts would then have to compete and “fight” with each other for an allocation of resources from the VM, which would then constrain the VM itself, limiting its performance, eventually leading to issues in gas and network usability

Application-specific blockchains addresses these shortcomings.


---

### Application-Specific Blockchains

Application-Specific Chains are customized blockchains made for one specific decentralized application.

In this article, I’ll be talking about **modular** app-specific blockchains in particular

They are built using modular architecture where the consensus and Data Availability functions are separated from the Execution function. An example of modular app-specific chains would be app-specific chains built on [Celestia](https://celestia.org/). A more in-depth dicussion on Celestia and modular architecture can be found in this article:

[https://mirror.xyz/knarb.eth/idZOlUKqxpFgs1mp22PJ4e7ismHquAY2hPyYUjk2i5A](https://mirror.xyz/knarb.eth/idZOlUKqxpFgs1mp22PJ4e7ismHquAY2hPyYUjk2i5A)

*Why modular app-specific chains?*

Traditional app-specific chains requires you to build every part of your own customized blockchain, that would mean building every single component including consensus, execution and data availability from the ground up. This requires a lot of resources.

For modular app-specific blockchains, you’d only need to build the execution layer which you can plug into Celestia for the consensus and data availability layers.

This saves time, resources and costs while providing the benefits that Celestia itself offers.


---

### Addressing Shortcomings

On top of the improved scalability and resource efficiency, modular app-specific blockchains also address the shortcomings of building on a shared environment and have a multitude of other pros

With modular app-specific blockchains that live natively on a data availability layer, such is the case by using Celestia, devs can build custom virtual machines with any network in mind. Cosmos SDK, Substrate, Weave, anything they want, it's their choice. This immediately solves the first problem previously mentioned, flexibility.

Since dApps on modular app-specific blockchains are not reliant on a shared environment’s governance, devs and the community would have significantly greater authority and sovereignty. They would not have to wait for an approval from an underlying blockchain’s governance if they wanted to make a decision. For example, if devs or the community wanted to fork or upgrade their dApp, modular app-specific chains allows you to do this without having to wait for any underlying blockchain’s governance. An example of this would be how dApps on Celestia would not need consent from Celestia itself if they wanted to do a fork, therefore solving the sovereignty problem.

Modular app-specific chains allows a dApp to maximize its performance without having to worry about the constraints of its underlying environment. dApps on a modular app-specific chain would never have to compete for an allocation of resources on they’re blockchain, unlike on a shared environment.


---

### Cross-Chain Communication

Cross-chain communication is the exchanging, reading and writing of data between different chains. Another word for it would be multi-chain interoperability. It’s how different chains like Ethereum, Solana and Avalanche are able communicate and interact with each other.

A benefit of modular app-specific chains is **trust-minimized** cross-chain communication between “clusters”

Clusters are groups of chains that perform trust-minimized communication

Every chain can perform cross-chain communication, whether it’s Ethereum to Solana, Ethereum to Polygon, Solana to Avalanche, etc. This is done by using trust assumptions, where you assume and trust that the chain and bridge you are communicating with is honest, reliable and will not steal your funds. This entire process is what’s called **trust-based** communication and poses some security risks as you are dependent on the honesty and reliability of the chain you are communicating with. Here’s a simple illustration to help you get a better understanding of this concept.

![Trust-based communication](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/X86C3MNY0R_5mYCVFjHBL.png?height=438&width=819)

Let’s use a case study of bridging between Ethereum and Polygon. When you bridge from Ethereum to Polygon, your funds will flow from the Ethereum chain to a bridge, then into the Polygon chain. See how, in this entire process, you are trusting the Polygon-Ethereum bridge to keep your funds safe and to not steal your funds. This process is **trust-based** as the bridge is a committee-based bridge which uses trust assumptions that require an honest **majority** assumption to sign off on communication. This poses a big security problem because you are exposing your funds to the bridge and in a worst case scenario, your funds get stolen.

Now, there is another type of communication called **trust-minimized** communication. This is a type of communication that requires weaker trust assumptions, meaning that it uses an honest **minority** assumption instead. This would mean that in the case of a dishonest majority in a committee-based bridge, the bridge can still continue to facilitate valid communication. There will then be significantly less security risk or risk that your funds will be stolen.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/3dBkco_i0Nuz3wLhpuLmy.png?height=449&width=830)

Now let’s use a case study of bridging between Ethereum and a rollup like Arbitrum. Say you want to bridge your funds from Ethereum Mainnet into Arbitrum. Since the main chain (Ethereum) assumes that the transaction is valid, but can also use fraud proofs to indirectly validate the transactions of the rollup (Arbitrum), then you wouldn’t need any trust assumptions for your funds to be safe.

A while back I mentioned about Clusters

So Ethereum and rollups like Arbitrum, Optimism and zkSync would be one cluster as they communicate with trust-minimized communication. Meanwhile, Ethereum and Polygon are 2 separate clusters as they communicate with each other using trust-based communication (trust assumptions). For a more in-depth explanation on clusters, you can refer to this article:

[https://blog.celestia.org/clusters/](https://blog.celestia.org/clusters/)

Now this obviously poses a problem because communication between different chains like Ethereum to Polygon, Ethereum to Solana, Ethereum to Cosmos, Cosmos to Polygon, etc. uses trust-based communication which has weaker security guarantees as it requires more trust assumptions. 

So, this is what the current landscape of cross-chain communication looks like:

![Current landscape of cross-chain communication](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/tHFlxNuTjUVYOVLfvoP7y.png?height=559&width=843)

You see how since Ethereum and its rollups communicate with each other with trust-minimized communication, they are in one cluster. That cluster then uses trust-based cross-chain communication when communicating with other chains like Polygon

*How can cross-chain communication be trust-minimized in order to reduce security risks?*

Any rollup or blockchain that shares a common data availability layer can make trust-minimized bridges with each other, either by fraud proofs, validity proofs or by directly validating the transactions, and a data availability layer is something that Celestia specializes in.

Celestia is a pluggable consensus and data availability layer, meaning that rollups or blockchains that want trust-minimized cross-chain communication can plug their execution layer onto Celestia, and *voilà*, enjoy trust-minimized cross-chain communication.

Here’s what the landscape of cross-chain communication in the future could look like with Celestia:

![Future landscape of cross-chain communication](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/s6qE5Z_d_RncDuZzVGlVu.png?height=588&width=829)

Celestia has the potential to become the core foundation for shared security and trust-minimized interoperability and communication between thousands, if not millions of rollups and blockchains in the future.


---

## Ending Note

By building on existing monolithic blockchains, the flexibility, sovereignty, performance and security of a dApp is far from optimal. Blockchains that communicate using trust-based assumptions relying on honest majority assumptions are flawed and face major security risks.

Modular app-specific chains that rely on trust-minimized cross-chain communication solves this by not only improving upon security, but by also significantly reducing the risk of funds being stolen.


---

*Thanks for reading! And a thank you to [Alex Beckett](https://twitter.com/likebeckett) and [Nick White](https://twitter.com/nickwh8te) for helping with proofreading! If you want to get notified about future posts or give any input/feedback, [subscribe](https://mirror.xyz/knarb.eth) and follow me on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/_knarb). Or don’t. It’s up to you.*

*This article was first published on 8 February 2022 in Substack. Minor edits were made for formatting. Thank you and goodbye.*

title: Centralization Vulnerabilities in Crypto Infrastructure
body:
Decentralization is one of the main selling points crypto has to offer, but few talk about (or turn a blind eye) to the fact that a large portion of the space, infrastructure in particular, is centralized or relies on centralized services.

![Essentially how a dApp communicates with a blockchain](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/tf0COnpPeRXVdyup61H0N.png?height=216&width=961)

A dApp that wants to communicate with an external blockchain network (Ethereum) would need something called Remote Procedure Call (RPC) Nodes. The process goes like this:

The dApp sends RPC requests to the nodes, and the nodes submits the RPC request execution to the external blockchain. The external blockchain sends the RPC response back to the dApp, through the nodes. This is what a decentralized process would look like, but for this to happen you would need full nodes, and running full nodes is costly and takes up a lot of effort.

This is where external RPC providers like Infura come in. Infura hosts their own full nodes and anyone that uses Infura gains access to Infura’s full nodes. So a dApp can just opt to use Infura instead of running and maintaining their own full nodes.

![dApp using Infura to communicate with an external blockchain](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/srI5XW7YCw573vkXtWEHb.png?height=359&width=1155)

The diagram above is meant to show how a dApp can use Infura’s full nodes to communicate with an external blockchain network. It’s a similar process to what was described before. The dApp sends RPC requests to Infura’s nodes, Infura’s nodes submits the RPC request execution to the external blockchain, the external blockchain then sends back the RPC response to the dApp, through infura’s nodes.

The problem lies in the fact that Infura itself is not fully decentralized and is reliant on Amazon Web Services. This opens up the possibility for the compromisation of data and a lack of privacy as data has to go through Infura’s RPC nodes.

A large portion of crypto infrastructure is reliant on centralized services like Infura and AWS. Per 2019, about [25% of Ethereum nodes were run on AWS](https://aws.amazon.com/blockchain/), while 5.5% were on Alibaba Cloud, 5.4% on Google Cloud and another 16.6% on other different cloud computing services. That’s over half of Ethereum nodes dependent on centralized services at the time.

![source: ethernodes.org](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/NGteLcx__bUvARIao8eSW.png?height=254&width=621)

Today, its 59.6% on AWS, 2.1% on Alibaba Cloud and 3.6% on Google Cloud. That’s more than half of Ethereum nodes dependent on a **single** centralized entity.

This not only goes against decentralization, but it presents a potential single point of failure. Back in late 2021 when AWS servers went down, “decentralized” exchange [dYdX went down with it](https://cointelegraph.com/news/aws-outage-hits-dydx-raising-concerns-over-decentralization).

Or 2020 when Infura suffered outages and [Ethereum dApps suffering alongside it](https://decrypt.co/47846/ethereum-backbone-infura-suffers-major-damage)

A lot of dApps on Ethereum rely on Infura while Infura itself relies on AWS servers, so if either one of the two goes down, so do all those dApps.

If **decentralized** applications are dependent on centralized services, then they’re not decentralized

*What is the solution?*


---

### Pocket Network

Pocket Network is an interesting proposition and one of many possible solutions to the centralization conundrum

Pocket network is a decentralized, middleware relay protocol that provides dApps access to communicate with external blockchains.

TCP/IP is what allows your computer to communicate with the internet.

Middleware is software that helps developers build applications more efficiently. More on middleware can be read here:

[https://insights.deribit.com/market-research/infrastructure-lego-the-middleware-thesis/](https://insights.deribit.com/market-research/infrastructure-lego-the-middleware-thesis/)

### How Pocket Network is Different to Infura

What differentiates Pocket Network to Infura is:

* Decentralization
* Resistance to network down times and censorship

***What makes it decentralized?***

Infura runs their nodes “in-house” and dApps use Infura services to gain access to their nodes.

Pocket Network don’t actually own a lot of nodes that are running on their network. The large majority of nodes running in Pocket Network are external, third-party node runners or validators that are incentivized to run and maintain their own nodes.

![Largest node runners in Pocket Network per block #55807. source: poktscan.com](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/MjlrE1m0jb9EB_7nxkuw6.png?height=682&width=704)

By using Infura, data goes through Infura itself which presents potential privacy issues as a compromising third party could view and abuse the data.

Pocket Network avoids this by relaying small different chunks of data through different, randomly selected nodes. By doing this, since a single node can only view a small random chunk of the data, no single node will be able to view the entire data thus addressing potential privacy and security issues.

***What makes it resistant to down times?***

![Geographical distribution of Pocket nodes runners in the world. source: poktscan.com](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/HmgbzGAmzcrGUJ6i4nUZp.png?height=396&width=770)

There are multiple different, independent external Pocket node runners that are scattered all over the world. If one set of nodes goes down, the protocol will reroute your RPC request to other available nodes.

In a scenario where all nodes in North America go down, dApps reliant on Pocket Network will continue to be live as they can connect and rely on Pocket node runners located in Europe and/or Asia.


---

### How Pocket Network Works

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/XwLWMvXT6bF4fh988Zx6L.png?height=402&width=1326)

It’s an identical process to what was discussed before. The dApp sends RPC requests to Pocket nodes, Pocket nodes submits the RPC request execution to the external blockchain, the external blockchain then sends back the RPC response to the dApp, through Pocket nodes.

What’s different this time is that Pocket network names their mechanism of regulating communication between dApps and nodes as **sessions**. When a dApp wants to use Pocket nodes, they would be put into a session where they are then pseudo-randomly connected to a set of nodes based on an algorithm for a limited time period. After this limited time period, the nodes connected to the dApp are tumbled and switched up to other nodes to promote privacy and security, while avoiding dependency on one particular set of nodes


---

### Incentives and Tokenomics

Incentives are the bread and butter on how Pocket Network works. It’s what attracts validators to want to run their nodes in Pocket Network.

**For validators/node runners:**

* To run a Pocket node you need to stake 15,000 $POKT
* They need to stake $POKT to run nodes because it keeps them honest about servicing relay requests
* Pocket node runners then earn rewards in $POKT based on the number of relay requests they service

**For dApps:**

* dApps wanting to access pocket nodes would need to stake $POKT, however, the amount they stake will depend on the amount of RPC relay requests they would need.
* More $POKT staked = more amount of RPC relays you can request
* So the larger, more congested the network, the more RPC relay requests you’d need, the more $POKT you’d need to stake

There’s a chain of events where the more POKT staked by a dApp, more RPC relays the dApp can request per session. The more RPC relays requested, the more rewards for node runners. More rewards for node runners attracts and incentivizes even more node runners which theoretically creates more demand for $POKT which is needed to be staked by validators.


---

### Conclusion

Centralized node providers like Infura are similar to SaaS companies where you pay a recurring subscription fee to access its services. In Pocket Network, you need to stake POKT tokens to access their services.

It’s a “stake to subscribe” model, where staking $POKT is a “membership” to Pocket Network and its nodes (from dApp’s POV) and it’s rewards (from validator’s POV). As long as you stake $POKT, you have membership or “one-time subscription” and once you un-stake $POKT, you lose access to pocket network.

In a landscape that’s constantly scaling, to remove centralized authorities and fulfill the promise of full decentralization, protocols like Pocket Network could be a possible step towards a truly decentralized space.


---

*Thanks for reading! If you want to get notified about future posts or give any input/feedback, [subscribe](https://mirror.xyz/knarb.eth) and follow me on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/_knarb). Or don’t. It’s up to you.*

*This article was first published on 12 April 2022 in Substack. Minor edits were made for formatting, updating data and any mentions of “Web3” were replaced because I don’t like that term. Thank you and goodbye.*

title: 从合约解读公售（以superful为例）
body:
[https://twitter.com/221133kk1](https://twitter.com/221133kk1)

最近有一款类似premint功能的网站上线，叫做superful，采取WL+freemint的形式发售

其功能对标premint，目前premint地板价0.7+，基于这个预期，superful白名单轮结束后，地板价表现得非常不错，一度接近0.3e

白名单轮结束后，还剩100多个在公售轮免费mint，时间是30日晚22点，大家以为又是一场gas war，但是结果出人意料，不少人在22点前就抢跑了；

![superful的opensea截图](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/xuOqpPdj-EVXx7tFcLcdy.png?height=443&width=1036)

今天这篇文章，主要从合约的角度，来看NFT公售具体是怎么回事，我们是否能做到抢跑；

首先，我们先找到superful的合约地址，如下：

[https://etherscan.io/address/0xc97a4c9773ebfbba0f32ff147b9b29972aba0b38](https://etherscan.io/address/0xc97a4c9773ebfbba0f32ff147b9b29972aba0b38)

![我们需要了解这两个合约的对象](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Qq2p__KwDV0NFgg7fUGff.png?height=333&width=1440)

我们点开这个NFT的合约，在写合约这边第四个，就是公售按钮，而且可以直接写，没有签名，也不需要填写价格和数量；

理论上，只要项目方设置开始mint，这边直接打出交易即可；

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/8gzzoLoau5usBV4KAHWUT.png?height=483&width=1364)

确认了公售的函数名称后（publicmint），我们去合约代码中，看一下这个函数可以启用的条件；

![启用条件](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/riuaZppl7Dw9YFQip9H7W.png?height=728&width=1385)

我们可以看到，公售启动的要求是：

!isAllowlistSale, "Public Sale has not started"

意思就是：只要allowlistsale还开启，那么公售就不能开始，所以我们去找allowlistsale这个函数；

结果如下：

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Dd7kVvRiHHYXy4UiW29E3.png?height=567&width=1362)

目前的结果是false，也就是allowlistsale结束（白名单轮结束），公售按钮处于启动状态

在公售开始前，这个值是true，所以，我们其实只要知道，项目方什么时候把这个值设置成了false，我们就可以去打mint了，项目方说22：00，我们就真的去等整点，那很可能会打不到

这也是很多次，我们发现，每次公售都有人比预定的时间抢跑几秒甚至几十秒；

那么，我们看一下，项目方是什么时间把这个allowlistsale的值改掉的？

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/aaDAd_-wJWLVWs5gxy0Qm.png?height=876&width=1257)

我们在创建者的合约上一看，原来在21：59：12（合约上的时间是UTC时间，+8才是北京时间）的时候，项目方设置了公售开启；

当时很多人监听了项目方的pending，在这个交互pending的时候就发出了mint请求，结果全部失败了，为什么呢？

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/paDwkgry9xo9xDHLiNAUr.png?height=151&width=1344)

原来，项目方开启公售需要2个开关，真正开启公售的时间是set paused的这个时间，也就是allowlistsale变成flase的38秒之后。

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/zIEcocjRn1acrR6tsn4vD.png?height=883&width=1184)

所以，我们看一件有趣的事情：

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/scU74wUj-SXVWMK3D2BV_.png?height=805&width=1362)

有个小哥手贱（钱包地址：0x051d39c0f2104561dfab8dbabc4b3aed5c8dc0b8），擅自设置allowlistsale的参数，当然因为他不是合约的创建者，这个设置没成功；

但是骗了很多监听合约的钱包，一窝蜂的发publicmint请求，这些钱包只要监听到设置allowlistsale的交易正在pending，就会同时发送publicmint请求，以争取在同一个区块内发送交易；

很显然，这些钱包都被耍了，粗略数了一下，大概有近1000个钱包被耍了，发送了Publicmint请求；

话说，科学家们也太内卷了，上千个钱包去抢100多个公售（/(ㄒoㄒ)/\~\~）

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/NvyR889YOfNJAwQlEFACD.png?height=254&width=1364)

然后，这些科学家又被耍了第二遍，这次是项目方设置了allowlistsale的参数变更，于是这些钱包又再次发送publicmint请求，看图，又是满满的几页，全部失败；

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/w5pysLCL6WNKDw5qNH2GQ.png?height=320&width=1366)

直到15244202区块，项目方设置了开启，才能真正的去发送publicmint请求，看下具体时间：

北京时间21：59：50，所以如果你盯着10点去发送交易的话，是不能进入0区块打包交易的，因为实际上提前10秒就可以开始打了；

![0区块打包交易](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/0Y3GbP2i7SaV68Z2F3czO.png?height=1049&width=1363)

我们可以看到，最下面的set paused 的区块是15244202，上面成功的publicmint都是在这个区块内完成的；

看下图，在下一个区块15244203，已经不能保证全部成功了，也就是说，你不能在0区块打出去交易，最多还能在下一个区块尝试一下，一个区块只有十几秒时间；

也就说，你在22：00：07秒之前，没有把交易打出去，就已经没有机会了。

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/5Sr3QrJw-I_k--JjUzVx1.png?height=700&width=1370)

写到这里，从合约角度解读superful的公售就完成了，最后给大家发个小工具，用来监听链上动态：

[https://explorer.blocknative.com/?v=1.34.2&0=ethereum&1=main](https://explorer.blocknative.com/?v=1.34.2&0=ethereum&1=main)

如图，当我们通过上文，判断出公售开启的条件后，我们就去监听NFT创建者的合约（不直接监听NFT合约是因为NFT的transactions太多，噪音太大）

![我们把创建者合约输入到这里](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/OrkvCNEg0D_ZWPQ6kXwEA.png?height=654&width=1640)

当我们监听到这个NFT创建者合约，进行了某项设置，我们就可以同时发送mint请求了，这样就有机会卡到0区块或者1区块，把mint请求发出去了。

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/RB6bxiwtVugyviaz4C7bR.png?height=592&width=1383)

\-END-
